user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_CallOnce:
```c
void UT_Stub_CallOnce(void (*Func)(void))
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *OnceEnt;
    UT_EntryKey_t        FuncKey;
    int32                i;

    if (Func == NULL)
    {
        return;
    }

    FuncKey = (UT_EntryKey_t)Func;
    OnceEnt = NULL;
    StubPtr = UT_StubTable;
    for (i = 0; i < UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS; ++i)
    {
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED && OnceEnt == NULL)
        {
            OnceEnt = StubPtr;
        }
        else if (StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALL_ONCE && StubPtr->FuncKey == FuncKey)
        {
            OnceEnt = StubPtr;
            break;
        }
        ++StubPtr;
    }

    if (OnceEnt == NULL)
    {
        /* should never happen -- UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS needs increase if it does */
        UtAssert_Abort("Cannot do CallOnce - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
    }
    else if (OnceEnt->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        OnceEnt->EntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALL_ONCE;
        OnceEnt->FuncKey   = FuncKey;

        Func();
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UT_Stub_CallOnce:
static UT_StubTableEntry_t UT_StubTable[UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS] = {{0}}
...
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
#define UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS 200
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No unreachable code: UtAssert_Abort contains a single call to UT_BSP_DoText and no statements after it, so there are no code paths that cannot be reached. Even if UT_BSP_DoText were a non-returning function, that does not introduce unreachable code within this function because there are no subsequent statements. Therefore Rule 2.1 is not violated.
